citation.article-title: Methylophilus quaylei sp. nov., a new aerobic obligately methylotrophic bacterium

p.s: Description of Methylophilus quaylei sp. nov.
Methylophilus quaylei (qu.ay’le.i N.L. gen.n. quaylei of Quayle; named after the prominent British biochemist J.R.
Quayle who first discovered the RuMP cycle of formaldehyde assimilation).
Gram-negative non-motile rods, 1.0–1.6 μm in length and 0.3–0.6 μm in diameter.
Multiply by binary fission.
Colonies on K-methanol agar are white, with entire edge, convex, translucent to opaque.
Strictly aerobic, obligate methylotroph utilizing only methanol as the growth substrate.
Able to grow at 10–32 °C and pH 5.0–8.5 with 0.05–0.5% (w/v) NaCl and optimally at 25–29 °C, pH 6.5–7.5, 0.05% (w/v) NaCl.
Catalase, oxidase and urease positive.
Reduce nitrate to nitrite.
Produce indole from tryptophan.
Assimilate methanol carbon via the RuMP pathway.
Assimilate NH4 via the glutamate cycle.
The tricarboxilic cycle is incomplete due to the absence of α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.
The glyoxylate shunt enzymes are absent.
Nitrate, ammonia and urea are used as nitrogen sources.
The prevailing cellular fatty acids are C16:0 and C16:1.
The major ubiquinone is Q8.
Cardiolipin (diphosphatidylgycerol) is absent.
Under nitrogen limitation, cells form an exopolysaccharide consisting of rhamnose, glucose and galactose.
Do not grow on peptone yeast extract medium.
DNA G+C content is 54 mol% (Tm).
The GenBank accession number for the 16S rDNA gene sequence of strain MTT is AY772089.

The type strain M. quaylei MTT was isolated as an airborne contaminant of methanotrophic culture in the Moscow fermentation plant and is deposited in the Russian Collection of Microorganisms as VKM B-2338T and in the German Collection of Microorganisms as DSMZ-, etc.
